TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AT A GLANCE

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  Water sector performance and sector reforms. With a population of 96.2 million in 2019, 
Viet Nam’s access to water supply increased from 65% in 2000 to 95% in 2017.1 In 2020, the 
water supply system in Viet Nam has a total treated water production capacity of 9.5 million cubic 
meters per day with piped water supply coverage in urban areas reaching 88%. The improvement 
has been driven by the government’s sector reforms, which started in 2007 through gradual 
equitization of state-owned water utilities.2 In 2007–2009, the government issued key water 
legislation to transform water from a social commodity to a commercial commodity. Water supply 
tariffs are set on a full cost-recovery basis. Water supply service companies are required to 
comply with ambitious targets in reducing non-revenue water to 18% by 2020, from an average 
of 30% in 2010. As of January 2020, about 110 private or partly state-owned water supply service 
companies were operating across Viet Nam. 
 
2.  Sector challenges. In 2017, the government decided to fully open its provincial water 
service companies to private sector ownership. However, the ongoing reform faces various 
institutional and financial challenges. First, the Ministry of Construction is responsible for policies 
and regulations governing water supply for urban areas and industrial zones, and the provincial 
people’s committees (PPCs), i.e., the provincial governments, manage service delivery. The 
challenges are whether (i) such devolution of responsibility is matched with accountability in terms 
of complying with central regulations and standards, and performing obligations to users; and 
(ii) PPCs can effectively fulfill their roles in planning, implementing, managing, and operating 
essential  services,  with  necessary  accountability  mechanisms  in  place.  There  is  limited 
contractual relationship between water supply service companies and PPCs in many provinces, 
despite the government’s regulatory guidance. Limited oversight at the central and provincial 
levels poses the risk of a privatized water supply service company steering its strategic business 
decisions towards maximizing returns rather than ensuring equitable and affordable public service 
delivery.  
 
3.  Second, a privatized water service company faces the following challenges: (i) weak legal 
basis of operation and therefore low commitment to improve service standards because of the 
absence of contractual relationships with PPCs, (ii) limited access to financing for long-term 
investments because of insufficient creditworthiness, and (iii) slow transformation of operations 
and corporate culture from a state-owned enterprise to that of a fully privatized commercial entity. 
Since water supply tariffs are approved by PPCs, transferring financial obligations from the 
government (public) to the private sector by reducing the government’s ownership can expose 
the water supply service companies to heightened risk of financial unsustainability. Developing 
equitable and financially sustainable water supply service in Viet Nam through sector reform 
requires continuous support to provide access to financing and enhance privatized water supply 
service companies’ creditworthiness and institutional and operational capacity. 
 
4.  Project  identification.  Since  2011,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  been 
supporting Viet Nam’s water sector reform through a $1 billion multitranche financing facility. The

ongoing Water Sector Investment Program3 helps selected Vietnamese water supply service 
companies improve their service and invest in key infrastructure by providing access to sovereign-
guaranteed financing. Building on the sovereign program, ADB and the Binh Duong Water 
Environment Joint Stock Company (BIWASE) have explored the potential for private sector 
(nonsovereign) financing since 2019.4 ADB’s Southeast Asia Regional Department and Private 
Sector Operations Department, working as one team, concluded that ADB can tailor its support 
to BIWASE through a combination of nonsovereign corporate loan and technical assistance (TA). 
 
5.  Project rationale. Binh Duong province, where BIWASE operates and which adjoins Ho 
Chi Minh City, is one of the fastest developing provinces in Viet Nam. The province has attracted 
$5.7 billion in foreign direct investment since 2016. More than 25 industrial zones and clusters, 
including the Vietnam–Singapore Industrial Park, provide jobs to nearly 1.3 million local workers 
and more than 500,000 foreign workers. Provincial water demand increased annually by 16%–
20% during 2016–2019, and BIWASE projects that the provincial water demand will exceed its 
production capacity by 2020–2021. 
 
6.  Project design. The project will support the expansion by 100,000 cubic meters per day 
of water production capacity of the Tan Hiep Water Treatment Plant in Binh Duong province. The 
capacity will serve domestic consumption and industrial zones in Ben Cat town, Tan Uyen town, 
and Thu Dau Mot city. The expansion includes additional water intake pumps and 9 kilometers of 
raw water transmission pipes from the Dong Nai River and the downstream distribution network.

II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
7.  Financial  management  and  business  planning.  BIWASE’s  financial  management 
capacity is adequate as it successfully implements sovereign loan projects financed by ADB and 
the Japan International Cooperation Agency. However, BIWASE needs to improve further to 
complete its transition from state-owned to commercial entity. Improvements include (i) adopting 
International Financial Reporting Standards to better communicate with potential domestic and 
international investors; and (ii) developing a long-term corporate business strategy and plan to 
adapt to future climate risk and necessity of mobilizing financing from various sources. 
 
8.  Legal framework. Binh Duong PPC and BIWASE agreed on the service areas, and state-
owned water supply service assets have been transferred. Water supply tariff calculations in Binh 
Duong follow the national government regulations that provide guidance, methods, and an 
equation which provincial governments shall use for appraising and approving tariff levels.5 The 
water tariff plan for 2018–2022 has been approved by the Binh Duong PPC after being appraised 
by the Department of Finance, Department of Construction, and Department of Labor and Social 
Affairs. However, BIWASE and the Binh Duong PPC need to strengthen their legal framework by

9.  The attached TA complements the project by strengthening BIWASE’s creditworthiness 
and institutional capacity to provide sustainable and affordable water supply services. The TA will 
(i)  provide  capacity  building  on  financial  management  and  climate-resilient  business  and 
operational planning and (ii) enhance the legal foundation of the business and operational 
framework between BIWASE and the Binh Duong PPC. The TA will be administered by ADB. 
BIWASE will closely coordinate with the Binh Duong provincial government. The TA will be 
included in the upcoming country operations business plan for Viet Nam.7 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
10.  The  outputs  will  result  in  the  following  outcome:  BIWASE’s  creditworthiness  and 
institutional capacity enhanced. The transaction TA will have outputs and activities as outlined in 
Table 1. 
 
11.  Output 1: Binh Duong Water Environment Joint Stock Company’s creditworthiness, 
climate-resilient water business and operations, and corporate governance enhanced. The 
output includes (i) training on financial management including financial reporting aligned with 
International Financial Reporting Standards; (ii) climate- and disaster-resilient operational support 
training on asset management, equipment maintenance, and non-revenue water reduction using 
an  enhanced  data  and  information  management  and  decision  support  system;  and 
(iii) preparation and implementation of a business plan including expected capital investment and 
reinvestment requirements in the medium to long term (e.g., 30 years). 
 
12.  Output 2: Binh Duong Water Environment Joint Stock Company’s legal basis of 
business and operations enhanced. The service agreement between BIWASE and the Binh 
Duong PPC will be improved with appropriate key performance indicators based on international 
and Vietnamese best practices. A reliable monitoring and reporting mechanism will be established 
between BIWASE and the Binh Duong PPC.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of 
Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund (eAKPF) and administered by ADB. Funds from 
the eAKPF will be used for activities and expenditure items eligible for financing by eAKPF. The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.
